title: Naming artifacts
data:
- *For the method for creating artifacts, see [Sting](/wiki/Sting "Sting") or [Orcrist](/wiki/Orcrist "Orcrist") (and in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") also [Elfrist](/wiki/Elfrist "Elfrist")).*

The **naming artifacts** trick refers to an [exploit](/wiki/Bug "Bug") in certain versions of *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* that let you [identify](/wiki/Identify "Identify") certain item types.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)
  - [1.1 Post-3.4.3](#Post-3.4.3)

- [2 History](#History)

- [3 Variants](#Variants)

  - [3.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [3.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)

## Description

Early versions of NetHack, such as [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), kept track of which items are [artifacts](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") through their names, allowing a flexible artifact set (i.e., multiple artifacts can be of the same item type) without needing separate fields in the object structure to track artifact status. As a consequence of this mechanic, the game needed to prevent non-artifacts being turned into artifacts via naming them (e.g. naming a long sword "Excalibur" to turn it into [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur")). So if you tried to name a non-artifact with the name of an artifact of the same base type, the game would prevent you and you will mis-engrave. ("Your hand slips...")

In later versions of NetHack, items used a separate "artifact flag" to identify whether they were artifacts (and which artifact they were), meaning that this mechanic was no longer necessary to prevent inadvertent creation of artifacts, but it remained in the codebase. This made it possible to identify items; for example, naming a helmet "The Mitre of Holiness" would fail *if and only if* the helmet is a helm of brilliance.

By this exploit, you could identify (or rule out) the following items:

| Appearance                                  | Item type                                                           | Artifact name                                                                            |
| ------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [amulet](/wiki/Amulet "Amulet")             | [amulet of ESP](/wiki/Amulet_of_ESP "Amulet of ESP")                | [The Eye of the Aethiopica](/wiki/The_Eye_of_the_Aethiopica "The Eye of the Aethiopica") |
| [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") | [luckstone](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone")                            | [The Heart of Ahriman](/wiki/The_Heart_of_Ahriman "The Heart of Ahriman")                |
| magic [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm")\*           | [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance") | [The Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/The_Mitre_of_Holiness "The Mitre of Holiness")             |

\*: The appearances of magic helmets are [randomized](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") - [plumed helmet](/wiki/Plumed_helmet "Plumed helmet"), [etched helmet](/wiki/Etched_helmet "Etched helmet"), [crested helmet](/wiki/Crested_helmet "Crested helmet"), and [visored helmet](/wiki/Visored_helmet "Visored helmet").

Although this exploit never appeared on the official bug list, it was fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"); naming any item in the the appropriate category, if you haven't identified its type, with the appropriate name, will mis-engrave whether or not the item's type is the artifact's base. Thus, attempting to name an unidentified gray stone "The Heart of Ahriman" will fail, regardless of whether it's a luckstone or touchstone, but if you've formally identified it as a touchstone you can name it successfully (and ineffectively).

### Post-3.4.3

The original fix in 3.6.0 still allowed a slightly different exploit with the same results, relying on the fact that formatting (capitalization and article placement) is corrected only for the actual type -- if naming the item in all lowercase, the exploit still works. Similarly, if using the correct capitalization but dropping the article (e.g. naming a [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") "Heart of Ahriman" instead of "[The Heart of Ahriman](/wiki/The_Heart_of_Ahriman "The Heart of Ahriman")"), the missing article will be inserted only if the type matches the artifact.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The artifact-naming trick is fully patched as of [commit d886b43](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/d886b43107d57235ca0d7d464ab2a9f8660b855b).

## History

NetHack 3.0.0 lacked an artifact marker on items, but instead checked the name and object base type of an item to determine whether it is an artifact; this allowed naming Sting or Orcrist to work, but the game had to forbid naming attempts that would create other artifacts. In the code:

- [Source:NetHack\_3.0.0/do\_name.c#line157](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/do_name.c#line157 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/do name.c") which causes your hand to slip if you try – although with a different message.
- See [Source:NetHack\_3.0.0/weapon.c#line58](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/weapon.c#line58 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/weapon.c") for a call from the weapons code to the spec\_abon function that determines the to-hit bonus of an artifact, or [line143](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/weapon.c#line143 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/weapon.c") or [Source:NetHack\_3.0.0/mhitu.c#line674](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/mhitu.c#line674 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/mhitu.c") for other similar calls.
- [Source:NetHack\_3.0.0/artifact.c#line237](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/artifact.c#line237 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/artifact.c") contains the definition of spec\_abon, which calls the function get\_artifact to determine whether an item is an artifact.
- get\_artifact in [line109](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/artifact.c#line109 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/artifact.c") compares the base type and name of the item to those in the artifact tables [above](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/artifact.c#line12 "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/artifact.c").

## Variants

Many variants adopt the aforementioned fixes for the artifact-naming trick, with some exceptions.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the artifact naming trick remains unpatched, and is even more effective due to the addition of new artifacts.

Below is a list of artifacts that are compatible with the naming artifacts trick:

| Appearance                                  | Item type                                                                       | Artifact name                                                                                                       |
| ------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [bag](/wiki/Bag "Bag")                      | [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding")                         | [Wallet of Perseus](/wiki/Wallet_of_Perseus "Wallet of Perseus")[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)                               |
| [candle](/wiki/Candle "Candle")             | [magic candle](/wiki/Magic_candle "Magic candle")                               | [The Candle of Eternal Flame](/wiki/The_Candle_of_Eternal_Flame "The Candle of Eternal Flame")[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) |
| [amulet](/wiki/Amulet "Amulet")             | [amulet of ESP](/wiki/Amulet_of_ESP "Amulet of ESP")                            | [The Eye of the Aethiopica](/wiki/The_Eye_of_the_Aethiopica "The Eye of the Aethiopica")                            |
| [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") | [luckstone](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone")                                        | [The Heart of Ahriman](/wiki/The_Heart_of_Ahriman "The Heart of Ahriman")                                           |
| magic [boots](/wiki/Boots "Boots")          | [speed boots](/wiki/Speed_boots "Speed boots")                                  | [Whisperfeet](/wiki/Whisperfeet "Whisperfeet")                                                                      |
| magic [cloak](/wiki/Cloak "Cloak")          | [cloak of displacement](/wiki/Cloak_of_displacement "Cloak of displacement")    | [Deluder](/wiki/Deluder "Deluder")                                                                                  |
| magic [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves")       | [gauntlets of dexterity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_dexterity "Gauntlets of dexterity") | [Gauntlets of Defense](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_Defense "Gauntlets of Defense")                                           |
| magic [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet")       | [helm of brilliance](/wiki/Helm_of_brilliance "Helm of brilliance")             | [The Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/The_Mitre_of_Holiness "The Mitre of Holiness")                                        |
| magic [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet")       | [helm of telepathy](/wiki/Helm_of_telepathy "Helm of telepathy")                | [The Crown of Saint Edward](/wiki/The_Crown_of_Saint_Edward "The Crown of Saint Edward")                            |
| [whistle](/wiki/Whistle "Whistle")          | [magic whistle](/wiki/Magic_whistle "Magic whistle")                            | [The Storm Whistle](/wiki/The_Storm_Whistle "The Storm Whistle")[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)                               |

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) Trivially identifiable in SLASH'EM with the showweight option enabled.
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) Trivially identifiable by having a light radius of 3, vs. 2 for normal candles.
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) Easily identified by applying it.

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), items can now bear the same name as an artifact, removing the ability to determine object identities this way.

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Naming artifacts

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
For the method for creating artifacts, see Sting or Orcrist (and in SLASH'EM also Elfrist).

The naming artifacts trick refers to an exploit in certain versions of NetHack that let you identify certain item types.

Contents

  • 1 Description
    • 1.1 Post-3.4.3
  • 2 History
  • 3 Variants
    • 3.1 SLASH'EM
    • 3.2 GruntHack

Description

Early versions of NetHack, such as NetHack 3.0.0, kept track of which items are artifacts through their names, allowing a flexible artifact set (i.e., multiple artifacts can be of the same item type) without needing separate fields in the object structure to track artifact status. As a consequence of this mechanic, the game needed to prevent non-artifacts being turned into artifacts via naming them (e.g. naming a long sword "Excalibur" to turn it into Excalibur). This made it possible to identify items; for example, naming a helmet "The Mitre of Holiness" would fail if and only if the helmet is a helm of brilliance.

By this exploit, you could identify (or rule out) the following items:

Appearance Item type Artifact name
amulet amulet of ESP The Eye of the Aethiopica
gray stone luckstone The Heart of Ahriman
magic helm* helm of brilliance The Mitre of Holiness

*: The appearances of magic helmets are randomized - plumed helmet, etched helmet, crested helmet, and visored helmet.

Although this exploit never appeared on the official bug list, it was fixed in NetHack 3.6.0; naming any item in the the appropriate category, if you haven't identified its type, with the appropriate name, will mis-engrave whether or not the item's type is the artifact's base. The original fix in 3.6.0 still allowed a slightly different exploit with the same results, relying on the fact that formatting (capitalization and article placement) is corrected only for the actual type -- if naming the item in all lowercase, the exploit still works. Similarly, if using the correct capitalization but dropping the article (e.g. naming a gray stone "Heart of Ahriman" instead of "The Heart of Ahriman"), the missing article will be inserted only if the type matches the artifact.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

The artifact-naming trick is fully patched as of commit d886b43.

History

NetHack 3.0.0 lacked an artifact marker on items, but instead checked the name and object base type of an item to determine whether it is an artifact; this allowed naming Sting or Orcrist to work, but the game had to forbid naming attempts that would create other artifacts. In the code:

  • Source:NetHack_3.0.0/do_name.c#line157 which causes your hand to slip if you try – although with a different message.
  • See Source:NetHack_3.0.0/weapon.c#line58 for a call from the weapons code to the spec_abon function that determines the to-hit bonus of an artifact, or line143 or Source:NetHack_3.0.0/mhitu.c#line674 for other similar calls.
  • Source:NetHack_3.0.0/artifact.c#line237 contains the definition of spec_abon, which calls the function get_artifact to determine whether an item is an artifact.
  • get_artifact in line109 compares the base type and name of the item to those in the artifact tables above.

Variants

Many variants adopt the aforementioned fixes for the artifact-naming trick, with some exceptions.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, the artifact naming trick remains unpatched, and is even more effective due to the addition of new artifacts.

Below is a list of artifacts that are compatible with the naming artifacts trick:

Appearance Item type Artifact name
bag bag of holding Wallet of Perseus[1]
candle magic candle The Candle of Eternal Flame[2]
amulet amulet of ESP The Eye of the Aethiopica
gray stone luckstone The Heart of Ahriman
magic boots speed boots Whisperfeet
magic cloak cloak of displacement Deluder
magic gloves gauntlets of dexterity Gauntlets of Defense
magic helmet helm of brilliance The Mitre of Holiness
magic helmet helm of telepathy The Crown of Saint Edward
whistle magic whistle The Storm Whistle[3]
  1. ↑ Trivially identifiable in SLASH'EM with the showweight option enabled.
  2. ↑ Trivially identifiable by having a light radius of 3, vs. 2 for normal candles.
  3. ↑ Easily identified by applying it.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, items can now bear the same name as an artifact, removing the ability to determine object identities this way.
